conclusion: The velocity of an object is obtained by integrating its acceleration over time: v = ∫ a dt. Thus, the change in velocity is equal to the area under the acceleration-time graph.
Object A has constant acceleration a from t = 0 to t = t2.
Object B has linearly increasing acceleration from t = 0 to t = t2, starting at a = 0 and reaching a = a at t = t2.

premise: Object A has constant acceleration a from t = 0 to t = t2.
conclusion: The velocity of Object A at t1 is v_A(t1) = ∫_0^t1 a dt = a ⋅ t1.

premise: Object B has linearly increasing acceleration from t = 0 to t = t2, starting at a = 0 and reaching a = a at t = t2.
conclusion: The equation for acceleration of Object B is a_B(t) = (a / t2) ⋅ t.

premise: The equation for acceleration of Object B is a_B(t) = (a / t2) ⋅ t and t2 = 2t1.
conclusion: The slope of the acceleration graph for Object B is (a / 2t1).

premise: The equation for acceleration of Object B is a_B(t) = (a / t2) ⋅ t and t2 = 2t1.
conclusion: The velocity of Object B at t1 is v_B(t1) = ∫_0^t1 (a / 2t1) ⋅ t dt.

premise: The velocity of Object B at t1 is v_B(t1) = ∫_0^t1 (a / 2t1) ⋅ t dt.
conclusion: The integral of t from 0 to t1 is ∫_0^t1 t dt = [t^2 / 2]_0^t1 = t1^2 / 2.

premise: The integral of t from 0 to t1 is ∫_0^t1 t dt = [t^2 / 2]_0^t1 = t1^2 / 2 and v_B(t1) = ∫_0^t1 (a / 2t1) ⋅ t dt.
conclusion: The velocity of Object B at t1 is v_B(t1) = (a / 2t1) ⋅ (t1^2 / 2) = (a ⋅ t1) / 4.

premise: The velocity of Object A at t1 is v_A(t1) = a ⋅ t1 and the velocity of Object B at t1 is v_B(t1) = (a ⋅ t1) / 4.

conclusion: At time t1, the two objects do not have the same velocity.
